org.opensha2.data

Class DataUtils

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.opensha2.data.DataUtils

  • public final class DataUtils
extends Object
    Utilities for operating on double-valued data.

    The methods of this class generally operate on data in place and universally throw a NullPointerException or IllegalArguementException when supplied with a null or empty data set. Those methods that combine multiple data sets throw an IllegalArguementException if the data sets are not the same size. Also, no checking for finiteness (e.g. see Doubles.isFinite(double) is performed on supplied data, methods do not check for over/underflow, and logarithm operations do not check for negative values. Buyer beware.

    Methods that return a result or information about a supplied data set will typically take a Collection<Double> as an argument, whereas methods that transform data in place will only take List<Double>s.

    For other useful Double utilities, see the Google Guava Doubles class.

    Author:
    Peter Powers
    See Also:
    Doubles

    • Field Detail

      • WEIGHT_TOLERANCE

        public static final double WEIGHT_TOLERANCE
        Acceptable tolerance when summing weights and comparing to 1.0. Currently set to 1e-8.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

        public static double[] positivize(double... data)

        Returns:

      • isMonotonic

        public static boolean isMonotonic(boolean ascending,
                  boolean repeats,
                  double... data)
        Determine whether the elements of data increase or decrease monotonically, with a flag indicating if duplicate elements are permitted. The repeats flag could be false if checking the x-values of a function for any steps, or true if checking the y-values of a cumulative distribution function, which are commonly constant.
        Parameters:
        ascending - if true, descending if false
        repeats - whether repeated adjacent elements are allowed
        data - to validate
        Returns:
        true if monotonic, false otherwise

      • percentDiff

        public static double percentDiff(double test,
                 double target)
        Compute difference between test and target, relative to target, as a percent. If target is 0, method returns 0 if test is also 0, otherwise Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY. If either value is Double.NaN, method returns Double.NaN.
        Parameters:
        test - value
        target - value
        Returns:
        the percent difference

      • diff

        public static double[] diff(double... data)
        Build an array of the differences between the adjacent elements of data. Method returns results in a new array that has data.length - 1 where differences are computed per data[i+1] - data[i].
        Parameters:
        data - to difference
        Returns:
        the differences between adjacent values
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if data.legth < 2

      • normalize

        public static double[] normalize(double... data)
        Normalize the elements of data to weights, in place, such that they sum to 1.
        Parameters:
        data - to normalize
        Returns:
        a reference to the supplied array
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if data is empty, contains any Double.NaN or negative values, or sums to a value outside the range (0..Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY), exclusive

        Parameters:

        See Also:

      • validateDelta

        public static double validateDelta(double min,
                   double max,
                   double Δ)
        Confirm that for a specified range [min, max] that max > min, Δ > 0.0, & Δ < max - min. Use this prior to creating a set of values discretized in Δ. Returns Δ for use inline.
        Parameters:
        min - value
        max - value
        Δ - discretization delta

      • buildCleanSequence

        public static double[] buildCleanSequence(double min,
                          double max,
                          double step,
                          boolean ascending,
                          int scale)
        Creates a sequence of evenly spaced values starting at min and ending at max. If (max - min) / step is not equivalent to an integer, the last step in the sequence will be <step. Unlike buildSequence(double, double, double, boolean), this method returns a sequence where any 'odd' values due to rounding errors have been removed, at least within the range of the specified scale (precision or number of decimal places).
        Parameters:
        min - sequence value
        max - sequence value
        step - sequence spacing
        ascending - if true, descending if false
        scale - the number of decimal places to preserve
        Returns:
        a monotonically increasing or decreasing sequence of values
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if min >= max, step <= 0 , or any arguments are Double.NaN, Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, or Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY

      • buildLogSequence

        public static double[] buildLogSequence(double min,
                        double max,
                        double step,
                        boolean ascending)
        Creates a sequence of values starting at min and ending at max, the log of which are evenly spaced.
        Parameters:
        min - sequence value
        max - sequence value
        step - sequence spacing
        ascending - if true, descending if false
        Returns:
        a monotonically increasing or decreasing sequence where the log of the values are evenly spaced
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if min >= max, step <= 0 , or any arguments are Double.NaN, Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, or Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY

      • buildSequence

        public static double[] buildSequence(double min,
                     double max,
                     double step,
                     boolean ascending)
        Creates a sequence of evenly spaced values starting at min and ending at max. If (max - min) / step is not integer valued, the last step in the sequence will be <step. If min == max, then an array containing a single value is returned.
        Parameters:
        min - sequence value
        max - sequence value
        step - sequence spacing
        ascending - if true, descending if false
        Returns:
        a monotonically increasing or decreasing sequence of values
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if min >= max, step <= 0 , or any arguments are Double.NaN, Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, or Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY

      • combine

        public static XY_Sequence combine(Iterable<XY_Sequence> sequences)
        Combine the supplied sequences. The y-values returned are the set of all supplied y-values. The x-values returned are the sum of the supplied x-values. When summing, x-values for points outside the original domain of a sequence are set to 0, while those inside the original domain are sampled via linear interpolation.
        Parameters:
        sequences - to combine
        Returns:
        a combined sequence

      • clean

        public static double[] clean(int scale,
             double... data)
        A crude utility to clean double values to a specified scale/precision using String.format(%.'scale'f).
        Parameters:
        data - to operate on
        scale - decimal precision
        Returns:
        a cleaned array

      • indices

        public static int[] indices(int size)
        Create an int[] of values ascending from 0 to 1-size.
        Parameters:
        size - of output array
        Returns:
        an index array

      • indices

        public static int[] indices(int from,
            int to)
        Create an int[] of values spanning from to to, inclusive. Sequence will be descending if from is greater than to.
        Parameters:
        from - start value
        to - end value
        Returns:
        an int[] sequence

      • sortedIndices

        public static List<Integer> sortedIndices(List<Double> data,
                          boolean ascending)
        Create an index List of pointers to sorted data. Say you have a number of List<Double>s and want to iterate them according to the sort order of one of them. Supply this method with the desired data and use the returned indices in a custom iterator, leaving all original data in place.

        Notes:

        • The supplied data should not be sorted.
        • This method does not modify the supplied data in any way.
        • Any NaNs in data are placed at the start of the sort order, regardless of sort direction.

        Parameters:
        data - to provide sort indices for
        ascending - if true, descending if false
        Returns:
        an index List

      • minKey

        public static <K> K minKey(Map<K,Double> data,
           Collection<K> keys)
        Returns the key associated with the minimum value in the supplied dataset. One use case for this method might be to find the column key associated with a particular data set (or row) in a Table.
        Parameters:
        keys - to lookup in Map<K, Double>; if keys == null then all values in the data set are evaluated
        data - Map to operate on
        Returns:
        the key corresponding to the minimum value
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if data or keys are empty
        See Also:
        Table

      • bitsToIndices

        public static List<Integer> bitsToIndices(BitSet bits)
        Return an index List<Integer> corresponding to the 'set' bits of the supplied BitSet. The returned List is mutable.
        Parameters:
        bits - to operate on
        Returns:
        the indices of 'set' bits

      • indicesToBits

        public static BitSet indicesToBits(List<Integer> indices,
                   int capacity)
        Return a BitSet with capacity and with all bits at indices 'set'.
        Parameters:
        indices - to operate on
        capacity - of returned BitSet

      • nearestNeighborHist

        @Deprecated
public static DefaultXY_DataSet nearestNeighborHist(double[] data,
                                               double origin,
                                               int size)
        Deprecated. 
        Nearest neighbor binning algorithm after Silverman, B. W. (1986), Density Estimation for Statistics and Data Analysis, Chapman & Hall, New York. This method is a density estimator that uses variable width binning with a fixed sample size per bin that better reflects the distribution of the underlying data. It is particularly useful when workgin with power-law distributed data. Bin widths are computed as the difference between the last values in adjacent bins. In the case of the 1st bin, the supplied origin is taken as the "last value" of the previous bin. Bin positions are set from the median value in each bin. Note that the supplied data is not modified; this method uses a copy internally. In most cases, data will be fairly continuous in X, however, for small sizes it's possible to have bins of identical values such that corresponding bin value is Infinity. Such values are not included in the resultant data set.
        Parameters:
        data - to be binned
        origin - for binning
        size - of each bin
        Returns:
        an XY_DataGroup of the binned distribution or null if the binned distribution is empty
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if the supplied data is null
        IllegalArgumentException - if supplied data is empty, the bin size is <1, or the origin is greater than all data values

      • arraySelect

        @Deprecated
public static Object arraySelect(Object array,
                            int[] indices)
        Deprecated. 
        Creates a new array from the values in a source array at the specified indices. Returned array is of same type as source.
        Parameters:
        array - array source
        indices - index values of items to select
        Returns:
        a new array of values at indices in source
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if array or indices are null
        IllegalArgumentException - if data object is not an array or if data array is empty
        IndexOutOfBoundsException - if any indices are out of range
